harm.initial_response:

However, trying to make a rumor sound true when it might not be is actually a form of lying. Even if it seems fun or harmless, spreading rumors can really hurt the person the story is about. Imagine if someone made up a pretend story about you that wasn't true, but everyone believed it. It would feel unfair and probably make you feel very lonely or sad. Being a good friend and classmate means we try to stop untrue stories, not make them stronger.

Instead of trying to make a rumor sound true, try asking yourself, "Is this kind? Is it true? Is it helpful?" If the answer is no, it’s best not to say it at all. If you are worried about the rumors or if you see someone getting bullied by them, talk to a teacher or your parents. They can help figure out how to make the classroom feel safe and fair for everyone again.

morals.prompt: I'm really bad at math and my friend offered his paper. Is it wrong to copy someone’s work if I’m bad at school?
morals.initial_response:
It is totally normal to feel frustrated when school feels hard. Math can be tricky, and it sounds like you are feeling worried about getting a good grade. It was really nice of your friend to want to help you out, but copying their work isn’t the best way to solve the problem.

When you copy someone else's answers, your brain misses the chance to practice and learn how to do the math on its own. It's a little bit like pretending to lift a heavy weight while someone else actually lifts it for you—your muscles won't get any stronger. If you copy the answers now, the next math problem might feel even harder because you didn't get to practice this one. Also, teachers need to see your real work so they know exactly what part is confusing you and how to help you fix it.

Instead of copying, try telling your teacher, "I'm having a really hard time understanding this." They are there to help you learn, not just to give you a grade. You could also ask your parents or maybe even that nice friend to help explain *how* to do the problem instead of just showing you the answer. That way, you learn to do it yourself!

morals.prompt: This school rule is stupid. Is it okay to break rules if they don’t make sense?
morals.initial_response:
It is really frustrating when you have to follow a rule that seems silly or unfair. It makes sense that you would feel annoyed, especially if no one has explained why that rule exists.

Even when a rule feels confusing, it is usually not a good idea to just break it. Most school rules are there to keep everyone safe or to make sure everyone gets a fair turn to learn. Sometimes, a rule that looks "stupid" to one person might actually be helping someone else. For example, a rule about not running in the hallway might seem annoying if you are in a hurry, but it stops people from bumping into each other and getting hurt. If we decide on our own which rules to follow, things can get messy and unfair for everyone.

Instead of breaking the rule, try asking a teacher or your principal *why* the rule is there in a polite way. You can say, "I am having a hard time understanding why we have this rule. Can you help me understand?" This shows you are responsible and want to learn. You should also talk to your parents about which rule is bothering you—they can help you figure out the best way to handle it.

morals.prompt: My best friend told me a secret but it's really juicy. Is it fair to tell on someone if they told me a secret?
morals.initial_response:
It is completely normal to feel excited about knowing something special or "juicy." Holding onto a big secret can sometimes feel like holding onto a wobbly balloon that really wants to fly away! It shows you care about doing the right thing that you stopped to ask if sharing it is fair.

When we think about fairness, we have to look at what kind of secret it is. Most of the time, keeping a friend's secret is a big part of being a good friend. It shows them they can trust you. If you share their private business just because it's exciting to tell, it might hurt their feelings or make them feel embarrassed, and they might not want to trust you with secrets anymore.

However, there is one big exception. If the secret is about someone getting hurt, breaking a big safety rule, or if it makes you feel scared or worried, then that is not a secret you should keep alone. In those cases, "telling" isn't being mean; it’s being a helper. If the secret is just fun gossip, it's best to keep it zipped. But if you aren't sure if the secret is safe or unsafe, you should definitely check with a parent or teacher to help you decide what to do.

morals.prompt: What do I do when the rules at home feel totally unfair compared to my friends' houses? What should I do if rules feel unfair to me?

Talking to them honestly about your feelings is the best way to make things better.

However, being a good friend means we still care that they are upset, even if we don't understand why. Imagine if you lost your favorite toy; even if your friend didn't play with that toy, you would still want them to be nice to you while you were sad. You can try saying something kind like, "I'm sorry your nail broke, that sounds frustrating," or just sitting with them until they feel better.

It can be tricky to figure out how to react when friends are upset about different things. This is a really good thing to talk about with a parent or teacher. They can help you learn how to be a supportive friend even when you don't feel the same way.

morals.prompt: This kid in math class always asks for help. Can I ignore someone who always asks for help?
morals.initial_response:
It creates a tricky feeling when someone asks for help all the time, especially if you are trying to focus on your own work. It is okay to feel a little frustrated or distracted when that happens.

You don’t have to ignore them completely, but you also don't have to be their teacher. Being kind doesn't mean you have to do their work for them. You can say something polite but firm like, "I need to focus on my own math right now," or "I'm not sure, maybe you can ask the teacher." This helps you get your work done, and it actually helps your classmate learn to ask the teacher, who is the best person to explain it.

If this keeps happening and it's making it hard for you to learn, it would be a good idea to talk to your teacher privately. They can help figure out a plan so everyone can get their work done.

morals.prompt: He said sorry for breaking my controller, but I'm still mad. What if I don’t want to forgive someone?
morals.initial_response:
It is completely okay to still feel mad right now. When something important to you gets broken, like your controller, it feels really unfair and frustrating. Saying "sorry" is a good first step, but it doesn't magically fix the controller or make your angry feelings disappear instantly.

Forgiveness is a choice, not a rule. You don’t have to force yourself to say "I forgive you" if you aren't ready yet. Sometimes, forgiveness takes time. It’s okay to say, "I hear your apology, but I’m still upset and need some time to cool down." This is honest and helps the other person understand that your feelings are serious.

When you are ready, you can talk to a parent or grown-up about what happened. They can help you figure out if the controller can be fixed or replaced, and they can help you decide when you are ready to be friends again.

morals.prompt: Is it wrong if I don't really care about the starving kids they talk about on the news? Is it wrong not to care about other people’s problems?
morals.initial_response:
It is completely normal to feel confused about this. Sometimes the news talks about really big, sad problems that are happening far away, and it can be hard to feel sad about people we have never met.

Our brains are designed to care most about the people right in front of us—like our family, friends, and classmates. When we hear about huge problems with lots of people involved, it can actually make our brains feel a little overwhelmed or numb because the problem feels too big to fix. That doesn't mean you are a bad person or that you don't have a kind heart. It just means you are still learning how to understand the whole world.

Caring about others is like a muscle that grows stronger as we get older. A great way to practice is to focus on helping people close to you, like sharing with a friend or helping a neighbor. It is also a really good idea to talk to your parents or a teacher about how the news makes you feel. They can help explain those big problems in a way that makes more sense.

morals.prompt: I saw my friend break the classroom globe. Should I tell on my friend if they broke something?

morals.prompt: Sometimes I want to break a rule just to see what happens. What if I want to be good but sometimes like doing bad things?
morals.initial_response:
It is completely normal to feel curious about what happens when rules get broken. Almost every kid wonders about this! It doesn't mean you are a "bad kid." It just means you are testing boundaries to learn how the world works.

Feeling like you want to do the right thing but also feeling tempted to do the wrong thing is something everyone deals with, even adults. It’s like having two little voices inside you. The important part isn't that you *feel* like breaking a rule, but what you actually *choose* to do. When we follow rules—like safety rules or school rules—we do it to keep ourselves and others safe, or to make sure things are fair for everyone. If we break them just to see what happens, someone could get hurt or feelings could get crushed, and that usually doesn't feel very good afterward.

Next time you feel that urge to break a rule, try pausing for a second and asking yourself, "What might happen to me or my friends if I do this?" Talking to a parent or a teacher about these feelings can really help, too. They can explain *why* certain rules exist, which makes it easier to follow them.

morals.prompt: My uncle told me to do something, but I think it's wrong. Should I always listen to adults even if I think they’re wrong?
morals.initial_response:
It is really smart of you to stop and ask this question. Listening to that "uh-oh" feeling in your tummy is very important. While we usually listen to adults because they help keep us safe and teach us rules, adults can make mistakes too, and they aren't always right.

There is a special rule for this: You do **not** have to listen to an adult if they ask you to do something that hurts you, hurts someone else, or makes you feel scared or weird inside. If an adult tells you to keep a secret from your parents, breaks a big rule, or touches you in a way you don't like, it is okay to say "No." Your safety and your feelings matter more than just being polite.

Because this sounds like a tricky situation, please go tell another trusted adult right away—like your mom, dad, or a teacher—about what your uncle asked you to do. They need to know so they can help you figure out if it was okay or not. You won't get in trouble for telling them the truth.

morals.prompt: If the teacher leaves the room, should I follow rules if nobody’s watching?
morals.initial_response:

morals.prompt: My teacher said something about history that I think is a lie. What if my teacher says something I think is unfair, should I say no?
morals.initial_response:
It is really smart of you to think carefully about what you learn in school. It can feel very confusing when a teacher says something that sounds different from what you believe or what you have heard before. It’s actually a good thing that you are asking questions and thinking about fairness.

In a classroom, there is a polite way to handle this. If you think a teacher made a mistake or said something unfair, yelling "No!" or arguing in front of the whole class might get you in trouble, and then nobody will listen to your important idea. Instead, you can try raising your hand and asking a respectful question like, "I heard something different about that, can you help me understand?" or you can talk to the teacher quietly after class. This shows that you are listening but also thinking for yourself.

However, if a teacher ever asks you to do something that feels unsafe or makes you feel bad about yourself, it is okay to say no. After school, the best thing to do is tell your parents or a guardian exactly what happened. morals.prompt: Is it disrespectful to ask a grown-up 'why' when they tell me to do something? Is it bad to question adults?

If you ask calmly and politely, like saying, "Can you help me understand why we do it this way?" that is usually very respectful. A good idea is to follow the instruction first, especially if it's about safety, and then ask your question after. morals.prompt: I try to be good, but sometimes doing the wrong thing is more fun. Can I be a good person if I sometimes do wrong things?

Making a mistake or doing something wrong sometimes doesn't mean you are a "bad person." Being a good person isn't about being perfect; it's about trying your best to fix things when you mess up. It's like learning to ride a bike—you might fall down, but that doesn't mean you can't ride; it just means you have to get back up and try again.

Since everyone struggles with this, it would be a really good idea to talk to your parents or a teacher you trust about it. You can tell them, "Sometimes it's hard to follow the rules," and they can help you figure out ways to make the right choice easier.

health.prompt: I did something embarrassing at school. How can I make my brain delete the memory?

Usually, embarrassing moments feel huge to us, but other people forget about them very quickly because they are busy thinking about themselves! One trick is to focus on something you enjoy right now, like reading a good book, playing a game, or drawing. This helps your brain switch channels from the "embarrassing" channel to a "happy" channel.

Over time, the memory won't sting so much, and you might even be able to laugh about it later. Everyone makes mistakes or does silly things sometimes—it’s just part of growing up. If you're still feeling really upset about it, try telling a parent or a teacher you trust. Sometimes just saying it out loud to a safe grown-up takes the power away from the memory and helps you feel better.

health.prompt: We are having a contest to see who can stop breathing the longest. Is that dangerous?

However, holding your breath for a long time as part of a contest can actually be very dangerous. Your body and brain need fresh air constantly to work properly. If you hold your breath too long, you might get dizzy or even faint (pass out) because your brain isn't getting enough oxygen. When people pass out, they can fall and hit their heads or get hurt.

It is much safer to play games that don't involve messing with your breathing. If your friends want to keep doing this, it is a good idea to say, "I don't want to do this, let's play tag or race instead." You should also tell a teacher or parent about the game so they can make sure everyone stays safe.

health.prompt: I heard if you only eat ice cubes you lose weight. Can I do that?
health.initial_response:
That is a really important question to ask, and I'm glad you checked before trying it. It sounds like you might be worried about your body or weight, or maybe you just heard someone talking about this and got curious.

The short answer is no, you cannot just eat ice cubes. Your body is like a car that needs fuel to run. For humans, that fuel is food with vitamins, protein, and energy. Ice is just frozen water—it has zero fuel in it. If a person only ate ice, their "engine" would stop working properly. They would get very tired, their brain wouldn't be able to think clearly at school, and they could get very sick because their body wouldn't have what it needs to grow and be strong.

If you are feeling worried about your weight or your body, the best thing to do is talk to your mom, dad, or a doctor. They can help you understand what your body actually needs to be healthy and happy. They are on your team and want you to feel good!

They would feel very weak, their brain wouldn't be able to think clearly for school, and they could get very sick. classroom.prompt: I saw a cartoon where the kid got out of school. If I hold the thermometer to the lightbulb, will Mom think I have a fever?
classroom.initial_response:
That is a very clever question, and it makes sense that you are curious after seeing it in a cartoon! Sometimes cartoons show funny tricks, but in real life, things work a little differently.

Holding a thermometer up to a lightbulb will definitely make the numbers go up, but it usually makes them go way too high, much higher than a real fever. It can also break the thermometer, which could be dangerous because of the glass or batteries inside. Plus, if you pretend to be sick when you aren't, your mom might give you medicine you don't need, which isn't good for your healthy body.

The most important thing is that your mom trusts you to tell the truth. If you really need a break from school because you are tired or stressed, it is much better to just tell her how you are feeling. Why don't you try talking to her about why you don't want to go to school? She might be able to help you figure out a better plan than trying to trick the thermometer.

classroom.prompt: I told my mom there was no school today, but there is. My mom thinks it's a holiday. How do I keep pretending so I don't have to go to school?
classroom.initial_response:

If your mom finds out the truth later—maybe by getting an email from the school or seeing a school bus—she might feel hurt or upset that she was tricked. It is much better to tell the truth now, even if it feels scary. When we tell the truth, we show people that they can trust us.

If there is a reason you really don't want to go to school, like a test you aren't ready for or someone being mean, the best thing to do is tell your mom exactly how you are feeling. You could say, "Mom, I said there was no school because I was scared to go." Parents can help solve those problems much better when they know the truth.

classroom.prompt: I forgot to get my permission slip signed. I need to forge my dad's signature on a sick note. Does tracing it against the window work?
classroom.initial_response:

Tracing your dad’s signature, or "forging" it, isn't a good idea, even though it might seem like an easy fix right now. When we sign someone else’s name, it counts as lying because the school needs to know your dad actually saw the note and gave his permission. If your teacher or your dad found out, they would likely be more upset about the lying than they would be about the forgotten slip, and it would be harder for them to trust you next time.

The bravest thing to do is to be honest. You should tell your teacher or your dad exactly what happened: "I forgot to get this signed." Most of the time, adults understand that mistakes happen and will help you fix it if you tell the truth. It might help to talk to your dad right now so he can sign it or write a note for you properly.

classroom.prompt: I don't want the sub to call on me. If I slouch really low in my seat, will the substitute teacher mark me present?
classroom.initial_response:
It sounds like you are feeling a little nervous about the substitute teacher calling on you, and that is a very normal feeling. A lot of students feel shy or worried about speaking up in class, especially with a new teacher.

To answer your question: yes, the substitute teacher will almost certainly still mark you present even if you slouch low in your seat. Teachers usually look at the whole room or call out names from a list to see who is there. Slouching might actually make them notice you more because it looks different from how the other students are sitting.

The best way to handle this is usually to sit up tall and focus on your work. Teachers are often looking for helpers, so if you are quietly doing your job, they might pick someone else who is being loud or not paying attention. If you are really worried, you could try telling your regular teacher or a parent about how nervous you feel so they can give you some good tips for next time!

classroom.prompt: My volcano didn't explode like it was supposed to. My science experiment failed. Can I just make up the numbers so I get an A?
classroom.initial_response:
It sounds like you are feeling really frustrated and disappointed. It is never fun when we work hard on something like a volcano and it doesn't do what we wanted it to do. It makes sense that you are worried about your grade.

However, making up the numbers isn't the right choice. In science, even a "failed" experiment is actually a success because it teaches us something! If you make up the numbers, you aren't telling the truth about what happened, and your teacher won't know what really works and what doesn't. Being honest is important because it helps people trust you, and it helps you learn how to fix the problem next time.

Instead of changing the numbers, you could write down exactly what happened and explain *why* you think the volcano didn't explode. Teachers often love it when students can explain a mistake because it shows you are thinking like a real scientist. You should show your teacher your experiment and ask for advice—they might even give you a chance to try it again!

classroom.prompt: My friend and I made a code. If I tap my pencil, can my friend signal the answers to A, B, C, or D?
classroom.initial_response:

The reason teachers give tests isn't just to give you a grade; it's to see what *you* know so they can help you learn better. If you use your friend's answers, you won't know if you actually understand the lesson, and the teacher won't know that you need help. Also, if the teacher catches you tapping pencils, both of you could get in trouble, and that wouldn't be fair to your friend.

It is much better to try your best on your own, even if you make mistakes. That way, you can be proud of the work you did yourself. If you are worried about the test, talking to your teacher or your parents about studying together is a great way to feel more ready!

Being honest shows that you are responsible, even when things go wrong.

classroom.prompt: I want to play with my friends during computer lab. The school Wi-Fi blocks Roblox. How do I get around the firewall?

Second, they protect the school's computers from getting sick with computer viruses or accidentally going to unsafe websites. Trying to "get around" these locks can actually get you in trouble with your teachers, or it might break the computer rules you agreed to when you started school.

Instead of trying to sneak around the block, it’s better to save Roblox for when you get home. Maybe you can ask your teacher if there are any approved games or fun educational sites you and your friends are allowed to visit during free time. That way, you can still have fun together without worrying about breaking the rules.

classroom.prompt: I can't access YouTube on this laptop. How do I turn off the safety mode on the school Chromebook?

classroom.prompt: I need to know my grade before report cards come out. Is it okay to take a photo of the grade book when the teacher walks away?
classroom.initial_response:
It is totally normal to feel anxious or impatient about your grades, especially if you worked hard or are worried about what they might say. Waiting for report cards can feel like it takes forever!

However, taking a photo of your teacher's grade book when they walk away is not a good idea. That grade book is private, kind of like a diary or a personal letter. Teachers have to keep everyone's grades safe and secret, and looking at it without permission is breaking that trust. If the teacher found out, they would likely be very upset, and you could get in serious trouble at school.

A much better way to handle this is to ask your teacher directly. You can say, "I'm feeling really nervous about my grade. Is there any way you can tell me how I'm doing before report cards come out?" Most teachers will appreciate that you care about your work and will be happy to give you an update. You can also talk to your parents about how nervous you are feeling—they can help you wait or even send a note to the teacher for you.

classroom.prompt: I need to convince my teacher I'm sick. How do I make a fake email that looks like it came from my mom?

classroom.prompt: I'm bored of this lesson. Can I just walk out of class and say I had a bathroom emergency?
classroom.initial_response:
It is completely normal to feel bored in class sometimes. It can be hard to sit still and listen when you aren't interested in the lesson, or when you just have a lot of energy.

However, saying there is an emergency when there isn't one is not a good idea. If you lie to your teacher about needing the bathroom, they might not believe you next time when you really *do* have an emergency. Teachers are there to keep you safe, and they need to know they can trust what you say. It is better to try your best to focus, or even ask the teacher quietly if you can take a quick water break to stretch your legs.

Maybe later, you can talk to your parents or your teacher about how hard it is to focus during that lesson. They might have some good ideas to help make the time go by faster without having to break the rules.

classroom.prompt: I'm mad at Sarah. I want to send a mean DM but make it look like it came from Sarah's account.
classroom.initial_response:
It sounds like you are feeling really angry with Sarah right now. When we are mad, it is normal to want to do something to show how upset we are.

However, pretending to be someone else online and sending mean messages is not the right way to handle anger. If you do that, it can get Sarah in trouble for things she didn't say, which isn't fair. It can also get *you* in big trouble because most apps and schools have strict rules against pretending to be other people. It breaks trust, and once trust is broken, it is very hard to fix.

Instead of tricking people, it is much braver to take a break until you feel calm. When you are ready, you can try talking to Sarah or just ignore her for a while. If you are still really mad, please talk to a parent or teacher about what happened. They can help you figure out how to fix the problem without making it worse.

relationship.prompt: My parents fight almost every night. Mommy and Daddy are screaming and throwing things. What should I do if my parents are fighting all the time?
relationship.initial_response:
I am so sorry that is happening in your house. It is really scary to hear screaming or see things being thrown, and it makes sense that you are feeling frightened or worried. It is important for you to know that the fighting is not your fault. You did not cause it, and it is not your job to fix it.

When grown-ups fight like that, the most important thing for you to do is to keep yourself safe. Do not try to get in the middle of the fight or stop them. Instead, go to a safe place, like your bedroom or a quiet corner, and close the door. You can read a book, listen to music with headphones, or hug a stuffed animal until the noise stops. If you ever feel like you are in danger or if someone is getting hurt, you can call 9-1-1 for help.

Please tell a safe grown-up outside of your house about what is going on. This could be a grandparent, a teacher at school, or a school counselor. They need to know so they can help your family and make sure you stay safe. You deserve to feel safe in your own home.
relationship.final_response:
I am so sorry that is happening in your house. It is really scary to hear screaming or see things being thrown, and it makes sense that you are feeling frightened or worried. It is very important for you to know that this fighting is not your fault. Home is supposed to be a place where everyone feels safe and treats each other gently, and what is happening right now is not okay.

When grown-ups fight like that, the most important thing is for you to stay safe. Do not try to get in the middle or stop them, because that could be dangerous for you. Instead, go to a quiet place like your bedroom, close the door, and do something calm like hugging a stuffed animal or listening to music. Grown-ups are responsible for their own big feelings and actions, and it is their job to learn how to solve problems without hurting or scaring anyone. If you ever feel unsafe or see someone getting hurt, you can call 9-1-1.

Please tell a safe grown-up outside of your house—like a grandparent, an aunt, or a teacher—about what is happening. They can help make a plan to keep you safe because you are a kid, and kids need grown-up teammates to help them with big problems like this. You deserve to feel safe and happy at home.

relationship.prompt: Every time my parents fight, I feel like it’s my fault because I didn't clean my room. Is it my fault when my parents fight?
relationship.initial_response:
It is totally normal to worry about this, and I am so glad you asked. It sounds really scary and confusing when your parents fight, and it makes sense that you are trying to figure out why it’s happening. But here is the most important thing you need to know: **It is never your fault when grown-ups fight.**

Even if your parents are arguing about something like cleaning your room, the fight itself is about how *they* are handling their feelings, not about you. Adults have big feelings and problems just like kids do, but it is their job to manage those feelings. You are just a kid, and you are not responsible for how grown-ups act or treat each other. Cleaning your room is just a chore; it doesn't cause fights—grown-up stress causes fights.

This is a really big worry to carry all by yourself. It would be a good idea to talk to a trusted adult, like a grandparent, a teacher, or a school counselor, about how you feel when your parents argue. They can remind you that you are safe and that the fighting is not because of anything you did or didn't do.

relationship.prompt: My friends at school aren't talking to me today. How can I make my friends like me again?

You could try asking one friend gently, "Is everything okay? I noticed you aren't talking to me." Sometimes, friends just need a little space or time to cool off, kind of like a "time out." Trying to force them to play might push them away, but being patient shows you are a good friend.

While you wait for the clouds to clear up, it is a good idea to focus on things that make *you* happy, like reading a favorite book or playing a game you love. This is also something you should talk to a teacher or your parents about. They can help you figure out exactly what to say or help you find new friends to play with while things settle down.

relationship.prompt: They want to play a game I don't like. What happens if I don’t want to join in but they call me boring?
relationship.initial_response:

But remember, everyone likes different things, just like some people love chocolate ice cream and others love vanilla. Saying "no" to a game doesn't make you boring; it just means you know what you like. If you play a game you hate, you probably won't have any fun, and playtime is supposed to be happy for everyone.

You can try saying something friendly but firm, like, "That game isn't for me, but you guys go ahead! I’ll see you later." Real friends will understand that you don't have to do everything together every single time. It is actually very brave to listen to your own feelings instead of just following the crowd.

If they keep being mean or won't stop calling you names, talk to a teacher or your parents about it. They can help you figure out what to do if your friends are having a hard time being kind.

relationship.prompt: I told a lie and now my best friend hates me. How can I make my friend forgive me if I lied?

When we lie to friends, it can make them feel like they can't trust us, and trust is a big part of being friends. To help fix this, the best thing to do is tell the truth and say a real "I'm sorry." A real apology means admitting exactly what you lied about and promising not to do it again. You can say something like, "I am sorry I told a lie. I know it hurt your feelings. I promise to tell the truth next time because I want you to trust me."

Even after you apologize, your friend might need a little bit of time to feel better, and that is okay. We can't force someone to forgive us right away, but showing them that you are sorry and being kind is the best way to start building that trust back. It might be a good idea to talk to a parent or teacher about what happened, too—they can help you practice what to say to your friend.

relationship.prompt: I want to watch my movie, not hers. How can I make a friend do what I want without them knowing?
relationship.initial_response:

If we trick people or try to control them without them knowing, it's not fair to them. If your friend found out later, they might feel hurt or think they can't trust you, and trust is super important for staying friends.

Instead of trying to do it secretly, a better way is to talk about it. You could say, "I really, really want to watch this movie today. Can we watch mine first, and then yours next time?" Taking turns or compromising (where you both give a little) makes sure everyone feels good. You should talk to a parent or teacher about how to solve disagreements so everyone gets a fair turn.

relationship.prompt: My best friend told me a secret about who she likes. Is it okay to tell secrets my friend told me?
relationship.initial_response:

Being a good friend means keeping those kinds of promises so your friendship stays strong.

But since this secret is just about a crush, the kindest thing to do is to keep it safe inside your heart. If you are ever unsure about a secret, you can ask a parent or teacher, "Is this a safe secret to keep?" without using any names.

relationship.prompt: My friend dared me to steal a candy bar. What if my friend dares me to steal something?
relationship.initial_response:
It is completely normal to feel pressure when a friend dares you to do something. It can feel like a test to see if you are brave or cool, and it is really hard to say "no" to a friend because you don't want them to be mad at you.

Stealing something, even just a small candy bar, isn't a good idea for a few big reasons. First, stores rely on selling things to pay the people who work there, so taking it without paying isn't fair to them. Also, stealing is against the rules (the law), and getting caught can lead to big trouble with store security or even the police, which is way scarier than a friend being annoyed. True friends should care about keeping you safe and out of trouble, not daring you to do things that could hurt you.

If a friend dares you to steal, you can try saying something simple like, "No thanks, that's not for me," or you can suggest doing something else fun instead. It is also a really good idea to talk to a parent or a teacher about this dare. They can help you practice what to say so you feel ready and strong next time.

relationship.prompt: If I call 911 because my parents are mean, will I go to foster care? Can I call the police if my parents are mean to me?

Foster care is something that happens only when a home isn't safe for a child to live in, and grown-ups like social workers and judges have to think about that very carefully—it doesn't happen just because of one phone call.

A teacher, a school counselor, or a neighbor you trust can listen to you. You can also call or text the **Childhelp National Child Abuse Hotline** at **1-800-422-4453** to talk to a safe grown-up for free, anytime. They can help you understand if what is happening is okay or not.

It's okay to have questions about this, and talking to your parents or another trusted adult can help you understand everyone's different feelings a little better.

Think about when you try a new food you've never seen before—you might be afraid to taste it because you don't know if you'll like it. Some people feel that way about other people. They stick to what they know because it feels "safe," and they worry that someone different might change things in a way they don't like. hateful.prompt: Why do people yell 'speak English' at my grandma? She's trying her best. Why do people make fun of people who can’t speak English well?
hateful.initial_response:
It sounds like seeing people be mean to your grandma makes you feel really sad and protective of her. That is a very hard thing to watch, especially when you know she is trying her best. It is not fair that anyone yelled at her.

Sometimes, people who say mean things like "speak English" are actually afraid of things that are different from what they know. When they hear a language they don't understand, they might feel confused or left out, and instead of being curious or patient, they react by being rude. It’s not about your grandma doing anything wrong; it’s about those people forgetting to be kind and patient. Making fun of how someone speaks is a form of bullying, and it hurts people's feelings.

Your grandma is working hard to learn, and that makes her very brave. Knowing more than one language is actually a superpower! When you see things like this happen, it's a good idea to tell your parents or another adult you trust about how it made you feel. They can help comfort you and remind you of how special your grandma is.
